Summary:

The patient is a 73-inch tall individual who is intubated and sedated due to respiratory distress and bronchoscopy. The patient has worsening bilateral symmetrical consolidation in both upper lobes and right middle lobe, likely due to pulmonary edema, and extensive consolidation within both lower lobes, potentially reflecting developing ARDS. The patient has also developed bilateral nonhemorrhagic pleural effusions, anemia, and ascites.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 39C (102.2F)
* Heart rate: 99-130 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 113/54 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 97%
* Height: 73 inches

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 9.4-12.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.5-8.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 195-212 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.5-0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 23-26 mg/dL
* Serum albumin: 2.1 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's medical issues include:

* Impaired skin integrity
* Impaired airway clearance
* Impaired balance
* Impaired muscle performance
* Impaired motor function
* Impaired posture
* Impaired ventilation
* Impaired cough
* Altered mental status
* Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* Dyspnea (shortness of breath)
* Tachycardia

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Respiratory failure due to worsening ARDS
* Sepsis or septic shock due to bacterial or fungal infection
* Cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to electrolyte imbalances
* Renal failure due to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease
* Neurological complications such as seizures or stroke due to hypoxia or electrolyte imbalances
* Gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding or perforation due to stress ulcer or ascites
* Venous thromboembolism (VTE) due to immobility and hypercoagulability
* Stress ulcer or bleeding due to corticosteroids or other medications
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Central nervous system complications such as meningitis or encephalitis due to sepsis or other infections.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for acute
   tachycardia/dyspnea, persistent fevers in setting of treatment for
   aspiration pneumonia.
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF this
   am, however, he appears to be more weak peripherally and concern that
   if he were extubated he would tire quickly and require reintubation.
   CXR is somewhat improved this morning and bilateral pleural effusions
   appear improved.   No evidence of underlying infection currently and
   pleural fluid from thoracentesis was transudative.  [**Month (only) 51**] also be a
   central component.
   - BAL for worsening Chest CT findings
 F/U results
 if pos for
   hemosiderin-laden Macros, then check ANCA, anti-basement membrane:
   pathology still pending.  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   - Attempt PSV/CPAP, wean sedation for NIF trial, keep TV low (400cc)
   for poss ARDS
   - Hold Tylenol
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive.  Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction and
   possible central pontine myelinolysis.
   - central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is okay,
   ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate neuron recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - [**Name2 (NI) **] need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Continue Keppra until outpt f/u with neuron for question of seizure
   activity on the floor
   - Simplify medication list to minimize chance of medications affecting
   mental status
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Now afebrile off all antibiotics,
   could represent drug fever
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - C. diff neg x 2
   - fluid collection in stomach, however not amenable to drainage due to
   location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   hold off on working it up further
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - will check respiratory virus screen.
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; unlikely since MRI brain did not show any bilateral
   hypothalamic lesions, less likely
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Was stable in low 130s. Now improving to mid-130s
   - Highest on differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes; will
   monitor Na for now and if worsens, do a trial of free water
   restriction.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue thiamine repletion
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.  Lasix 40 mg IV x 1
   given 2L positive yesterday.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian (placed [**4-4**]), A-line
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents
   .
   # Disposition: Pending above, consider trach/PEG if no improvement by
   next week

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 39-year-old male with a history of wet beri-beri, who was transferred to the ICU for acute tachycardia and dyspnea in the setting of treatment for aspiration pneumonia. The patient has been experiencing persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage, and has been diagnosed with anemia, hyponatremia, and coagulopathy.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.9C (100.3F)
* Heart rate: 115 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 137/72 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* SpO2: 99%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: cachectic, intubated, and sedated
* Cardiovascular: tachycardic and hyperdynamic
* Respiratory: tachypneic with coarse upper airway sounds and bilateral rhonchi
* Abdominal: soft, non-tender, and with present bowel sounds
* Neurologic: opens eyes to voice

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.7 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 212 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Sodium: 135 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.4 mmol/L
* Chloride: 25.1 mmol/L
* Calcium: 8.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient's respiratory support includes:

* Endotracheal tube
* Ventilator mode: CPAP/PSV
* Tidal volume: 470 mL
* Positive end-expiratory pressure: 10 cmH2O
* Fraction of inspired oxygen: 40%

The patient's medical complications include:

* Tachypnea and respiratory distress
* Tachycardia
* Altered mental status
* Fevers
* Anemia
* Hyponatremia
* Coagulopathy
* Beri-beri
* Possible central pontine myelinolysis

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Thiamine repletion
* Vit K and FFP for coagulopathy
* Lactulose for diarrhea
* Keppra for seizure activity
* Simplification of medication list
* Nutrition support
* Surveillance cultures
* Repeat LP if necessary
* F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Sepsis
* Multi-organ failure
* Central nervous system complications
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Electrolyte imbalances
* Thiamine deficiency

Based on the patient's condition and treatment plan, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory support. The patient's medical team should also be aware of the potential complications and be prepared to address them promptly if they arise.

1. Respiratory distress: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode. His RSBI is good, but he appears weak peripherally, and there is concern that he would tire quickly if extubated.
2. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is not fluid responsive and is likely related to fever, cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
3. Altered mental status: The patient has multiple etiologies for his altered mental status, including chronic EtOH ingestion, delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction, and possible central pontine myelinolysis.
4. Fevers: The patient has persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage, which could represent a drug fever or an ongoing infection.
5. Anemia: The patient has multiple reasons for being anemic, including malnutrition, illness, and guaiac-positive stools, which likely indicate a slow GI bleed.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is improving, but the highest differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes.
7. Beri-Beri: The patient has dry/wet features and echo hyperdynamic, which is being managed with thiamine repletion.
8. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy likely due to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition, which is being managed with vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma.
9. Etoh: The patient has a history of chronic EtOH ingestion and is being considered for withdrawal.
10. FEN: The patient is receiving tube feeds and has no IV fluids.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and tachypnea can lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and cardiomyopathy can lead to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
3. Infection: The patient's persistent fevers and lack of response to antibiotics can indicate an ongoing infection, which can spread to other parts of the body.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and guaiac-positive stools can indicate a slow GI bleed, which can worsen if not managed properly.
5. Central nervous system complications: The patient's altered mental status and possible central pontine myelinolysis can lead to central nervous system complications, such as seizures or brain herniation.
6. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's hyponatremia and coagulopathy can lead to electrolyte imbalances, which can worsen if not managed properly.
7. Vitamin deficiencies: The patient's beri-beri and coagulopathy can lead to vitamin deficiencies, which can worsen if not managed properly.

Based on the patient's current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and gastrointestinal status. Additionally, the patient's altered mental status and possible central pontine myelinolysis require close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

 delirium from current

The patient has a moderate bilateral pleural effusion, which is likely the main cause of tachypnea. The patient is hemodynamically stable, but has persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and bilateral pleural effusion increase the risk of respiratory failure.
2. Infection: The patient's persistent fevers and positive blood cultures suggest a high risk of infection, which can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and mortality.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's INR is elevated, indicating a coagulopathy, which can increase the risk of bleeding complications.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to malnutrition, illness, and gastrointestinal bleeding, which can increase the risk of cardiovascular complications.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to multiple etiologies, including delirium, central pontine myelinolysis, and liver dysfunction, which can increase the risk of falls, pressure ulcers, and other complications.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely due to SIADH, which can increase the risk of seizures, coma, and death if not treated promptly.
7. Beri-beri: The patient's beri-beri can worsen if not treated promptly, leading to cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure and arrhythmias.
8. Etoh withdrawal: The patient's Etoh withdrawal can lead to seizures, hallucinations, and other complications if not managed properly.
9. Coagulation disorders: The patient's coagulation disorders can increase the risk of bleeding complications, such as intracranial hemorrhage, if not managed properly.

To prevent these complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management by a multidisciplinary team, including intensivists, pulmonologists, infectious disease specialists, and other healthcare professionals. The patient's treatment plan should include aggressive management of respiratory failure, infection, coagulopathy, anemia, altered mental status, hyponatremia, beri-beri, Etoh withdrawal, and coagulation disorders.

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory distress is likely due to a moderate bilateral pleural effusion, which may worsen if not managed properly. The patient's ABG results show a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 345, indicating a moderate degree of hypoxemia.
2. Infection: The patient's persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage may indicate an ongoing infection. The patient's BAL and thoracentesis fluid cultures are negative, but the respiratory viral screen is uninterpretable due to lack of cells. Further investigation is needed to identify the source of the infection.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's INR is stable around 2, likely due to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition. The patient is at risk of bleeding complications, and close monitoring of coagulation parameters is necessary.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is improving, but the patient is at risk of developing SIADH due to pulmonary processes. Close monitoring of sodium levels is necessary to prevent further hyponatremia.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to malnutrition, illness, and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's hemoglobin level is 8.5 g/dL, and close monitoring of hemoglobin levels is necessary to prevent further anemia.
6. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to multiple etiologies, including delirium, central pontine myelinolysis, and liver dysfunction. Close monitoring of the patient's mental status is necessary to prevent further complications.
7. Beri-Beri: The patient's beri-beri is likely due to thiamine deficiency, and close monitoring of the patient's response to thiamine repletion is necessary.
8. Etoh Withdrawal: The patient is at risk of ethanol withdrawal, and close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and symptoms is necessary to prevent withdrawal symptoms.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding and diarrhea may worsen if not managed properly. Close monitoring of the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms is necessary to prevent further complications.
10. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's tachycardia and hyperdynamic echo may indicate cardiac complications, and close monitoring of the patient's cardiac status is necessary to prevent further complications.

The patient's care plan should include:

1. Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status to prevent further respiratory distress.
2. Further investigation to identify the source of the infection.
3. Close monitoring of the patient's coagulation parameters to prevent bleeding complications.
4. Close monitoring of the patient's sodium levels to prevent further hyponatremia.
5. Close monitoring of the patient's hemoglobin levels to prevent further anemia.
6. Close monitoring of the patient's mental status to prevent further complications.
7. Close monitoring of the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms to prevent further complications.
8. Close monitoring of the patient's cardiac status to prevent further complications.
9. Consideration of tracheostomy and PEG tube placement if the patient's respiratory and nutritional status does not improve by next week.
10. Close communication with the patient's family and healthcare team to ensure that the patient's care plan is being followed and that any changes are made promptly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 39-year-old male with wet beri-beri, a condition characterized by fluid accumulation in the body due to thiamine deficiency. The patient was admitted with acute tachycardia, dyspnea, and persistent fevers in the setting of treatment for aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Tachypneic, coarse upper airway sounds, and bilateral rhonchi. The patient has a good respiratory system index (RSBI) and negative inspiratory force (NIF) this morning, but appears more weak peripherally and may tire quickly if extubated.
* Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, hyperdynamic, and not fluid responsive. The patient's tachycardia is likely related to fever, cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
* Neurological: Altered mental status due to chronic EtOH ingestion, delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction, and possible central pontine myelinolysis.
* Fever: Persistent fevers despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage, which may represent drug fever.
* Anemia: The patient has multiple reasons to be anemic, including malnutrition, illness, and guaiac-positive stools. A slow gastrointestinal bleed is likely.
* Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium levels are improving, but the highest differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has a stable INR around 2, likely due to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition.
* Beri-Beri: The patient has dry/wet features, with an echo showing hyperdynamic cardiac function. Thiamine repletion is ongoing.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and coarse upper airway sounds suggest a high risk of respiratory failure, particularly if the patient is extubated.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hyperdynamic cardiac function may lead to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
* Infection: The patient's persistent fevers and broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage suggest a high risk of infection, particularly if the patient is immunocompromised.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and guaiac-positive stools suggest a high risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly if the patient's condition worsens.
* Central nervous system complications: The patient's altered mental status and possible central pontine myelinolysis suggest a high risk of central nervous system complications, such as seizures or visual problems.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hyponatremia and coagulopathy suggest a high risk of electrolyte imbalance, particularly if the patient's sodium levels worsen.
* Thiamine deficiency: The patient's beri-beri diagnosis suggests a high risk of thiamine deficiency, particularly if the patient's condition worsens.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue respiratory support, including CPAP/PSV and NIF trial.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac function and consider invasive monitoring if necessary.
* Investigate the patient's persistent fevers and consider repeating LP if all other investigations are negative.
* Continue thiamine repletion and monitor the patient's electrolyte levels.
* Consider repeat MRI brain to rule out any underlying central nervous system pathology.
* Consult with a neurosurgeon and consider tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) if the patient's condition does not improve by next week.

Summary:

The patient is a 39-year-old male with wet beri-beri, transferred to the ICU for persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fevers. He has a history of chronic ethanol ingestion and has been diagnosed with cardiomyopathy, liver dysfunction, and central pontine myelinolysis. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are unstable, with a temperature of 37.8C, heart rate of 119 bpm, and blood pressure of 161/80 mmHg. His respiratory status is also unstable, with a respiratory rate of 31 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 97%. He has a history of malnutrition, anemia, and coagulopathy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk of developing respiratory failure. His oxygen saturation is 97%, which is within the normal range, but his respiratory rate is 31 breaths per minute, which is higher than normal. His PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 275, which is within the normal range, but his respiratory rate is higher than normal, which may indicate respiratory failure.
2. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient has a history of cardiomyopathy and is at risk of developing cardiovascular complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.
3. Infection: The patient has a history of fevers and is at risk of developing infections. His white blood cell count is 12.7, which is within the normal range, but his differential count shows a shift to the left, which may indicate an infection.
4. Malnutrition: The patient has a history of malnutrition and is at risk of developing malnutrition-related complications such as weakness, fatigue, and decreased immune function.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has a history of coagulopathy and is at risk of developing bleeding complications such as hemorrhage and hemostasis.
6. Central Nervous System Complications: The patient has a history of central pontine myelinolysis and is at risk of developing central nervous system complications such as seizures, stroke, and cerebral edema.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has a history of malnutrition and is at risk of developing gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
8. Renal Complications: The patient has a history of hyponatremia and is at risk of developing renal complications such as acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is unstable, and he requires close monitoring and management. He requires further evaluation and treatment for his underlying conditions, including cardiomyopathy, liver dysfunction, and central pontine myelinolysis. He also requires management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and gastrointestinal symptoms. He requires close monitoring of his vital signs, including his temperature, heart rate, and blood pressure. He requires close monitoring of his respiratory status, including his oxygen saturation and respiratory rate. He requires close monitoring of his cardiovascular status, including his cardiac rhythm and blood pressure. He requires close monitoring of his gastrointestinal symptoms, including his nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. He requires close monitoring of his renal function, including his creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 39-year-old male with a complex medical history, including wet beri-beri, chronic ethanol ingestion, and acute illness. The patient is currently in the ICU for persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fevers.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has tachypnea and respiratory distress, with a RSBI of 98. He is on CPAP/PSV with a FiO2 of 40% and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has tachycardia, with a heart rate of 116 bpm, and is hypertensive, with a systolic blood pressure in the 140s-150s mmHg.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8, and is not following commands.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL, and is coagulopathic, with an INR of 2.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has diarrhea and is receiving tube feeds.
* Infectious: The patient has a fever, with a Tmax of 100.5F, and has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 12.7 K/uL
* Hct: 24.6%
* Plt: 25 K/uL
* Cr: 0.5 mg/dL
* TCO2: 26 mmol/L
* Glucose: 149 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 19.8/44.0/1.8, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 38/0.04/0.04, ALT/AST: 81/142, Alk Phos/T Bili: 192/1.2, Amylase/Lipase: 63/193, Differential-Neuts: 74.6%, Lymph: 14.2%, Mono: 7.1%, Eos: 3.6%, Lactic Acid: 0.7 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.1 g/dL, LDH: 280 IU/L, Ca++: 8.6 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 4.1 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and respiratory distress may progress to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiomyopathy.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status and coagulopathy may worsen, leading to neurological deterioration or even death.
* Infection: The patient's fever and coagulopathy may increase the risk of infection, which could be life-threatening.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's diarrhea and coagulopathy may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, which could be life-threatening.
* Kidney injury: The patient's coagulopathy and hypertension may increase the risk of kidney injury or failure.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Tracheostomy and PEG placement
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Vasopressors for hypertension
* Sedation and analgesia for respiratory distress
* Coagulation factor replacement therapy
* Nutritional support
* Gastrointestinal bleeding prophylaxis
* Infection prophylaxis

The patient's family would like to transfer him to a rehabilitation facility once he is medically ready, and the patient will require ongoing care and management in the ICU.

   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is okay,
   ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Consider d/c Keppra for possible drug rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Was afebrile off all antibiotics,
   which could represent drug fever, but now T max 100.5F [**4-11**]
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg x 2
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   hold off on working it up further
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Was stable in low 130s. Now improving to mid-130s
   - Highest on differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes; will
   monitor Na for now and if worsens, do a trial of free water
   restriction.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP today [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Consider d/c Keppra
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically
   ready.
   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability
   papers.
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 39-year-old male with a history of wet beri-beri, now transferred to the ICU for persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fevers. He has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics, but fevers persist. The patient has a tracheostomy and PEG placement planned for today. He has a rash on his trunk and extremities, likely an early drug rash. He is hypertensive and has a history of chronic EtOH ingestion, liver dysfunction, and dry beri-beri.

Potential medical complications:

1. Infection: The patient's persistent fevers and lack of response to broad-spectrum antibiotics suggest a potential infection. Further investigation is needed to identify the source of the infection.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and respiratory distress may worsen, leading to respiratory failure. Close monitoring of his respiratory status is necessary.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiomyopathy or arrhythmias.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status, likely due to delirium, may worsen, leading to further neurological complications, such as seizures or coma.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's anemia and guaiac-positive stools suggest a potential gastrointestinal bleed. Close monitoring of his gastrointestinal status is necessary.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
7. Skin complications: The patient's rash may worsen, leading to skin breakdown and infection.
8. Nutritional complications: The patient's malnutrition and lack of oral intake may worsen, leading to further nutritional complications.
9. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen, leading to seizures or other neurological complications.
10. Central pontine myelinolysis: The patient's history of central pontine myelinolysis may worsen, leading to further neurological complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Continue to investigate the source of the patient's infection and adjust his antibiotic regimen accordingly.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's coagulopathy and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's skin status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust his nutrition regimen as necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's hyponatremia and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's central pontine myelinolysis and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual who has been admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure, acute, with impaired airway clearance, ventilation, and cough.
* Impaired skin integrity, likely due to a drug rash.
* Impaired balance, muscle performance, motor function, and posture.
* Altered mental status, not delirium.
* Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin).
* Tachycardia.
* Hypertensive, with a systolic blood pressure in the 140s-150s mmHg range.

The patient is receiving various medications, including:

* Pantoprazole (Protonix) for stress ulcer prophylaxis.
* Fentanyl for pain management.
* Heparin sodium for prophylaxis of deep vein thrombosis.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, indicating an inflammatory response.
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and alkaline phosphatase (ALKP) levels, suggesting tissue damage or organ dysfunction.
* Elevated troponin-T levels, indicating possible cardiac injury.
* Elevated creatinine (Cr) and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, indicating renal dysfunction.
* Hypocalcemia (low calcium levels) and hypomagnesemia (low magnesium levels).

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Cachexia (wasting) and intubation.
* Tachycardia and hyperdynamic cardiovascular examination.
* Coarse upper airway sounds and bilateral rhonchi.
* Soft, non-tender abdomen with bowel sounds present.
* 2+ edema in dependent areas.
* Eyes open but not tracking, and not following commands.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure, which can progress to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* Sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Renal failure, which can worsen the patient's overall condition.
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
* Worsening of the patient's mental status, potentially leading to delirium or coma.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination findings. The patient's treatment plan should be regularly reassessed and adjusted as necessary to ensure optimal management of their condition.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a history of respiratory failure, impaired skin integrity, and other systemic complications. The patient's parents have verbally agreed to tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement, which is scheduled for tomorrow. The patient is currently NPO and requires 2 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) on call for the procedure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.1C, heart rate of 116 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 140/98 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 94% on 40% FiO2. The patient's respiratory support includes continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and pressure support ventilation (PSV) with a tidal volume of 567 mL and respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.7 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 225 K/uL. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 142 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 81 IU/L. The patient's blood glucose level is 149 mg/dL, and the patient's calcium level is 8.6 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and liver enzymes suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ failure.
3. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, which increases the risk of bleeding complications, especially during the tracheostomy and PEG placement procedures.
4. Infection: The patient's impaired skin integrity and respiratory support increase the risk of infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's impaired gut function and elevated liver enzymes increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hemorrhagic shock.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and cardiac failure.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fevers
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.  Trach placed [**4-11**].
   - Will attempt trach mask trial
   - Still awaiting BAL results (if pos for hemosiderin-laden Macros,
   pathology still pending).  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive.
   - stop captopril due to propensity to cause rashes
   - start metoprolol 12.5 mg TID and titrate upward as necessary
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - potential central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is
   okay, ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem) and was less febrile off all
   antibiotics.  Fever last night could represent drug fever.  ID has
   signed off, but will let them know that he is still spiking fevers.
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg multiple times
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   repeat MRI [**4-12**]
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Was stable in low 130s. Now improved to mid
   140s.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Keppra and captopril stopped
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian removed (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, peripheral,
   PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically
   ready.
   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability
   papers.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2191-4-11**] 05:22 PM 55 mL/hour

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:19.3/39.7/1.8, Lactic Acid:0.8 mmol/L,

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fevers
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.  Trach placed [**4-11**].
   - Will attempt trach mask trial
   - Still awaiting BAL results (if pos for hemosiderin-laden Macros,
   pathology still pending).  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive.
   - stop captopril due to propensity to cause rashes
   - start metoprolol 12.5 mg TID and titrate upward as necessary
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - potential central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is
   okay, ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem) and was less febrile off all
   antibiotics.  Fever last night could represent drug fever.  ID has
   signed off, but will let them know that he is still spiking fevers.
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg multiple times
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   repeat MRI [**4-12**]
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Was stable in low 130s. Now improved to mid
   140s.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Keppra and captopril stopped
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian removed (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, peripheral,
   PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically
   ready.
   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability

Summary:

The patient is a 39-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with wet beriberi, persistent tachycardia, and dyspnea. He has a history of chronic ethanol ingestion and has developed a morbilliform rash, likely caused by Keppra. The patient has been treated with antibiotics, but his fever persists. He has also developed coagulopathy, anemia, and hyponatremia. The patient's neurological status is altered, and he has been diagnosed with central pontine myelinolysis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's persistent fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis.
2. Central Nervous System (CNS) Infection: The patient's altered mental status and coagulopathy make it possible that he has a CNS infection, such as meningitis or encephalitis.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's tachypnea and respiratory distress may lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may indicate cardiac complications, such as cardiomyopathy or arrhythmias.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's anemia and guaiac-positive stools suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Central Pontine Myelinolysis: The patient's diagnosis of central pontine myelinolysis may lead to long-term cognitive and motor deficits.
7. Skin Breakdown: The patient's morbilliform rash and altered mental status increase the risk of skin breakdown and pressure ulcers.
8. Infection-Related Complications: The patient's persistent fever and coagulopathy make it possible that he has an underlying infection that may lead to complications, such as sepsis or organ failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and neurological status closely.
2. Administer antibiotics and antifungals as indicated by the patient's culture results.
3. Consider adding antiviral medication to the patient's treatment regimen if the patient's symptoms persist.
4. Continue to provide supportive care, including mechanical ventilation and vasopressors as needed.
5. Consider performing a tracheostomy to facilitate weaning from mechanical ventilation.
6. Monitor the patient's skin integrity and provide pressure ulcer prevention measures as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent complications.
8. Consider referring the patient to a rehabilitation facility once medically stable.

   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Consider d/c Keppra for possible drug rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Was afebrile off all antibiotics,
   which could represent drug fever, but now T max 100.5F [**4-11**]
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg x 2
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   hold off on working it up further
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Was stable in low 130s. Now improving to mid-130s
   - Highest on differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes; will
   monitor Na for now and if worsens, do a trial of free water
   restriction.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP today [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Consider d/c Keppra
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically
   ready.
   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability
   papers.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 39-year-old male with a history of wet beri-beri, chronic EtOH ingestion, and malnutrition, who is currently in the ICU due to persistent tachycardia, dyspnea, and fevers.

The patient has undergone several interventions, including tracheostomy, bronchoscopy with BAL, and placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube. He has also received multiple blood transfusions and has been treated with antibiotics, including meropenem.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 101.7F, heart rate of 119 bpm, and blood pressure of 145/73 mmHg. His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 98% on 40% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, hyponatremia, and coagulopathy. His liver function tests are elevated, with an ALT of 69 IU/L and an AST of 114 IU/L. His creatinine level is 0.4 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 27 mg/dL.

The patient's radiology results show a chest CT with findings consistent with wet beri-beri, and an MRI brain with findings consistent with central pontine myelinolysis.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is likely related to his fever, cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to multiple etiologies, including chronic EtOH ingestion, delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction, dry beri beri, and central pontine myelinolysis.
3. Fevers: The patient's fevers are persistent despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage, and are likely related to an underlying infection.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to malnutrition, illness, and gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely due to SIADH, and will be monitored for worsening.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is likely due to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition.
7. Rash: The patient developed a raised, blanchable lesion on his trunk, which may be related to a drug rash.
8. Etoh: The patient has a history of chronic EtOH ingestion, and is currently undergoing withdrawal.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but may deteriorate if his underlying infection is not treated.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may lead to cardiovascular instability.
3. Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status may worsen if his underlying central disease is not treated.
4. Infection: The patient's persistent fevers and coagulopathy make him at risk for infection.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and gastrointestinal bleeding may worsen if his underlying condition is not treated.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, including tachycardia, altered mental status, fevers, anemia, hyponatremia, coagulopathy, and rash. Potential medical complications that may arise include respiratory failure, cardiovascular instability, neurological deterioration, infection, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a chief complaint of continued fevers and a rash. The patient is intubated and on CPAP/PSV ventilation with an FiO2 of 40%. They are also receiving antibiotics via infusion.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37C, heart rate of 112 bpm, and blood pressure of 155/82 mmHg. Their respiratory rate is 21 inspirations per minute, and their SpO2 is 100%.

The patient has a morbilliform rash, which is more confluent. They also have tachycardia and are tachypneic with coarse upper airway sounds and bilateral rhonchi. Their abdominal exam is normal, with soft, non-tender bowel sounds. They have 2+ edema in their dependent areas.

Lab results show a white blood cell count of 8.7, hemoglobin of 8.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 198 K/uL. The patient's electrolytes are within normal limits, with a serum creatinine of 0.4 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen of 23 mEq/L. Their glucose level is 119 mg/dL.

The patient's respiratory failure is assessed as acute and not ARDS-related. They have impaired skin integrity, tachycardia, and dyspnea. The patient also has a fever, altered mental status, and impaired airway clearance, balance, muscle performance, motor function, posture, ventilation, and cough.

The patient is receiving nutrition via a Nutren 2.0 formula and has a glycemic control plan in place. They have an arterial line, a 16-gauge catheter, and a 20-gauge catheter in place. Prophylactic measures are being taken to prevent deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is acute and may worsen if their ventilation is not optimized.
2. Infection: The patient's fever and rash may indicate an infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hyperdynamic cardiovascular exam may indicate cardiac stress, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or failure.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and impaired motor function may indicate neurological damage or dysfunction, which could worsen if not addressed.
5. Skin complications: The patient's morbilliform rash may worsen if not managed properly, leading to skin breakdown and infection.
6. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance is positive, which may lead to fluid overload and subsequent respiratory and cardiac complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent these potential complications and optimize their clinical outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple complex medical conditions. The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.3C (100.9F)
* Heart rate: 112 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 155/82 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 21 inspirations per minute (IPM)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient has been experiencing fevers, which the ID team believes are likely due to a drug fever and rash. The patient has also had a trial of tracheostomy mask use, which was well-tolerated.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.7-9.7 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.4-9.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 198-232 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.4-0.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 23-24.9 mmol/L
* Serum albumin: 2.3 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L

The patient's radiology results include a head MRI, which is not specified as being abnormal or normal.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Impaired skin integrity
* Tachycardia
* Dyspnea (shortness of breath)
* Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Impaired airway clearance
* Impaired balance
* Impaired muscle performance
* Impaired motor function
* Impaired posture
* Impaired ventilation
* Impaired cough

The patient's ICU care includes:

* Nutrition: Nutren 2.0 (full) at 55 mL/hour
* Glycemic control: Not specified
* Lines: Arterial line, 16-gauge, and 20-gauge
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to the patient's fevers and altered mental status
* Pneumonia or respiratory failure due to the patient's respiratory rate and oxygen saturation
* Skin breakdown and pressure ulcers due to the patient's impaired skin integrity and immobility
* Delirium or worsening altered mental status due to the patient's tachycardia and altered mental status
* Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure due to the patient's tachycardia and hypertension
* Renal failure or acute kidney injury due to the patient's electrolyte imbalances and creatinine levels
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to the patient's altered mental status and impaired airway clearance
* Deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism due to the patient's immobility and risk factors for thrombosis.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fevers
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.  Trach placed [**4-11**].
   - Will attempt trach mask trial
   - Still awaiting BAL results (if pos for hemosiderin-laden Macros,
   pathology still pending).  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive.
   - stop captopril due to propensity to cause rashes
   - start metoprolol 12.5 mg TID and titrate upward as necessary
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - potential central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is
   okay, ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem) and was less febrile off all
   antibiotics.  Fever last night could represent drug fever.  ID has
   signed off, but will let them know that he is still spiking fevers.
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg multiple times
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   repeat MRI [**4-12**]
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Was stable in low 130s. Now improved to mid
   140s.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Keppra and captopril stopped
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian removed (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, peripheral,
   PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically
   ready.
   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability
   papers.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2191-4-13**] 12:00 AM 55 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2191-4-7**] 07:00 PM
   16 Gauge - [**2191-4-11**] 04:00 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2191-4-12**] 08:30 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:

The patient has a number of potential medical complications that can arise, including:

4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status could be due to central pontine myelinolysis, which can cause permanent cognitive and motor deficits.

8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition could lead to a range of complications, including weakness, fatigue, and impaired wound healing.
9. Skin breakdown: The patient's rash could progress to skin breakdown, which could lead to infection and other complications.
10. Central nervous system complications: The patient's MRI brain showed a small fluid collection extra-axially, which could indicate a central nervous system complication.

The patient's treatment plan includes antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals, as well as supportive care, such as mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and nutritional support. Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 39-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of wet beri-beri and persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fever of unknown origin. The patient has a history of chronic ethanol ingestion and is currently experiencing altered mental status, likely due to delirium from acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction, dry beri beri, and central pontine myelinolysis.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38.3C (100.9F)
* Heart rate: 112 bpm
* Blood pressure: 155/82 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.7-9.7 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 25.2-24.9%
* Platelet count: 232-198 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.5-0.4 mg/dL
* Total CO2: 28-30 mmHg
* Glucose: 119-105 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.3 g/dL
* LDH: 214 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.0 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Tachycardia: likely related to fever, cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease
* Altered mental status: due to multiple etiologies, including chronic ethanol ingestion, delirium from acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction, dry beri beri, and central pontine myelinolysis
* Anemia: likely due to malnutrition, illness, and slow GI bleed
* Hyponatremia: resolved, but may recur
* Beri-beri: dry/wet features, echo hyperdynamic
* Coagulopathy: likely due to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition
* Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions, possibly due to medication or infection
* Etoh: chronic ethanol ingestion, outside window for withdrawal
* FEN: replete electrolytes, on tube feeds

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Broad-spectrum antibiotics for fever
* Tracheostomy and mechanical ventilation for respiratory support
* Increased metoprolol for tachycardia
* Minimization of sedating medications for altered mental status
* F/u neuro recs for prognosis and treatment of altered mental status
* Repeat MRI head for follow-up
* Nutritional support with tube feeds
* Electrolyte management
* Coagulopathy management with vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Infection
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Central nervous system complications
* Coagulopathy
* Electrolyte imbalance
* Hypoglycemia
* Hypertension

It is essential to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and treatment response closely to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient remains in the ICU with ongoing respiratory failure, acute and impaired skin integrity, tachycardia, dyspnea, and fever. The patient's mental status remains altered, and they experience impaired airway clearance, balance, muscle performance, motor function, posture, ventilation, and cough.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 8.7-9.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.4 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 198-232 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.4-0.5 mg/dL
* Total CO2 (TCO2): 27-30 mmHg
* Glucose: 105-124 mg/dL
* Other laboratory results are within normal limits.

The patient's imaging studies show a small left subdural collection with unchanged appearance, and a geographic focal T2-signal abnormality in the central pons, which is consistent with central pontine myelinolysis.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.8C (100.1F)
* Heart rate: 112 bpm (91-112)
* Blood pressure: 158/75 mmHg (103-178/66-107)
* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute (18-35)
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and anticoagulants. They are also receiving nutritional support through a pulmonary diet and have a tracheostomy tube in place.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's fever and altered mental status
* Worsening of respiratory failure, potentially requiring invasive mechanical ventilation
* Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's coagulopathy and anticoagulant therapy
* Development of pressure ulcers or skin breakdown due to impaired skin integrity
* Further decline in mental status or development of delirium
* Worsening of muscle weakness or paralysis due to central pontine myelinolysis

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fever unknown origin
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.  Trach placed [**4-11**].
   - Cont trach mask
   - BAL results (neg for hemosiderin-laden Macros).  ANCA negand anti-GBM
   remains pending, but not likely to be positive.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Is staying
   normotensive.
   - Captopril d/c
d due to propensity to cause rashes
   - Increase metoprolol to 25 mg TID and titrate upward as necessary
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Appears to be improving. Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion, delirium from current acute illness, ICU
   setting, liver dysfunction, dry beri beri and central pontine
   myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. Repeat MRI shows unchanged small
   subdural defect and continued evolution of likely central pontine
   myelinolysis. Likely due to fast correction of hyponatremia on
   admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
s an irreversible
   process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs
 will follow up as outpatient
   - Repeat MRI head
 essentially unchanged
   - Cont to hold lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 added to allergy list
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem) and was less febrile off all
   antibiotics, wich is c/w drug fever.  ID agrees w/ drug fever.
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL negative
   - C. diff neg multiple times
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   repeat MRI [**4-12**], unchanged. [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however
   it
s a diagnosis of exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did
   not show any bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in
   differential.
   - recent sputum and urine pos for yeast
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
 have been negative recently
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
 no new issues
   .
   # Anemia: Stable HCT at 23-25 over past several days. Pt has many
   reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness, guaiac pos stools. Likely
   having a very slow GI bleed.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI changed to qday
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Was stable in low 130s. Now improved to mid
   140s. TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Na, Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR drifting down without treatment to 1.7. Likely due
   to alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this
   admission. Needs Vit K and FFP prior to invasive procedures.
   - follow coags/Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
 none to date
   - Keppra and captopril stopped for possible drug reaction
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.  Social Work following
   .
   # FEN: Replete electrolytes, stable on tube feeds.  Dobhoff in place as
   G tube cannot be placed in setting of  truncal rash.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt
 OOB to chair
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian removed (placed [**4-4**]), A-line to be d/c
   peripheral, Foley changed to condom cath
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Trach in place, Dobhoff until rash resolves. CM and PT
   screen for rehab: [**Hospital 189**] Rehab. Likely today. SW helping to file
   long-term disability papers.
